title: Culture, expansion, and flow-cytometry-based functional analysis of pteropid bat MR1-restricted unconventional T cells
procedures:
Step-by-step method details
Step-by-step method details
Part I: Pteropid bat MR1T cell culture and expansion
Timing: ∼14 days
The cultured pteropid MR1T cells can be used for functional assessment, including cytotoxicity and cytokine production. This expansion protocol enables higher cell numbers and a highly enriched population of MR1T cells at the end of culture, overcoming the challenge of resource limitations, including the need for large amounts of primary bat immune cells.
Critical: Viability of bat cells tends to be low. Thaw a few vials from multiple bats as a backup.
Note: This protocol is adapted from a human MAIT cell expansion protocol (Boulouis et al., 2020[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib1]). The overall timeline representation of Part I is depicted in Figures 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1] and 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2].

Initiation of primary culture from cryopreserved bat cells
Thawing of primary bat cells
Thaw cryovials in a water bath set at 37°C until a small piece of ice is left.
Transport cryovials into biosafety cabinet class-II (BSC-II) on wet ice.
Critical: Practice aseptic technique, keep everything sterile and work in a BSC-II from this step onwards.
In BSC-II, transfer cells into a sterile 50 mL falcon tube.
Add cold (2°C–8°C) R10 medium dropwise onto cells. Swirl tube to mix as media is being added. Mix well.
Note: This thawing step describes thawing of 107 cells/mL. For every 1 mL of cells, add 10 mL of media. Scale proportion of media and buffers accordingly.
Centrifuge tube at 390 x g for 5 min at 4°C.
Discard supernatant into diluted (10%) bleach. Resuspend cells with 10 mL of cold PBS. Centrifuge tube at 390 x g for 5 min at 4°C. Repeat step twice for a total of 3× PBS washes.

Resuspend pellet in 1 mL cold R10 medium and allow cells to recover at 23°C–25°C for 30 min.
Perform cell count by Trypan Blue exclusion. (Troubleshooting - Problem 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec6.1])
Critical: Keep reagents on ice and centrifuge cold at 4°C. Wash out DMSO thoroughly to minimize DMSO toxicity on bat immune cells. This recovery step is critical before culturing.
Culturing primary bat MR1T cells
Wash the cells by adding 10 mL PBS to cells, mix well and centrifuge tube at 390 x g for 5 min at 4°C.
Discard supernatant by inverting the tube and pipette out any excess residual liquid. Resuspend cells in complete expansion media (IC expansion medium (2× cytokines) diluted with base IC culture medium at 1:1 ratio), at 5 × 106 cells/mL.
Add 5-OP-RU to final concentration of 10 nM (x1000 dilution). Mix well and plate cells onto sterile 96-well U-bottom plate, at 200 μL per well (106 cells/well).
Incubate cells at 37°C in the 5% CO2 incubator.
Replace half volume of media with IC expansion medium (2×cytokines), every 2 days by pipetting out half volume of media and add back the equivalent volume. Mix well. If cells are accidentally disturbed during the media change, centrifuge supernatant and resuspend pellet with equivalent volume of fresh media before adding back to the wells.
Add 5-OP-RU at final concentration of 10 nM to cells on day 5 and 10.
Recover viable cells with Ficoll density gradient centrifugation as described (Dias et al., 2017b[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib5]) on day 11 .(Troubleshooting - Problem 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec6.3]).
Critical: 5-OP-RU degrades rapidly upon exposure to aqueous solution. Only add into culture media immediately before the intended experiments (within 2 min). Preferably work in a darkened BSC-II. We recommend titrating 5-OP-RU to determine the optimal concentrations for your experimental set-up.

Staining cells and flow-cytometry-based analysis on day 0, 10, and 14 post-culture
Note: This staining step is for routine monitoring of expanded culture.
Note: This is the most basic staining cocktail for Pa MR1T cell identification.
Transfer 106 cells into a 96-well V-bottom plate.
Wash once with 200 μL FACS buffer. Spin at 390 × g, 5 min at 4°C. Discard supernatant by pipetting.
(Blocking) Add 50 μL of 10% FCS or if available, 10% bat serum diluted in FACS buffer to block cells for 30 min at 4°C. Additionally, pre-block cells with human (h)MR1-6-FP fluorescent-conjugated tetramer diluted in FACS buffer for 40 min at 4°C.
Note: Initial pre-blocking experiments are recommended to determine the binding specificity of hMR1-5-OP-RU tetramer to pteropid MR1T cells (Leeansyah et al., 2020b[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib12]). Once this has been determined in your experimental set-up, the pre-blocking step may be omitted. We previously showed that hMR1-5-OP-RU tetramer binds with high specificity to Pa MR1T cells (Leeansyah et al., 2020b[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib12]). By contrast, through pre-blocking experiments with hMR1-5-OP-RU tetramer, we showed that hMR1-6-FP tetramer bind weakly and with low specificity to Pa MR1T cells (Leeansyah et al., 2020b[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib12]).
Wash cells with 150 μL FACS buffer. Spin at 390 × g, 5 min at 4°C. Discard supernatant by pipetting.
(hMR1-5-OP-RU tetramer staining) Stain cells with 50 μL diluted fluorochrome conjugated - hMR1-5-OP-RU and hMR1-6-FP tetramer for 40 min at 23°C–25°C, in the dark. (Troubleshooting – Problem 5[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec6.9])
Wash cells with 150 μL FACS buffer. Spin at 390 × g, 5 min at 4°C. Discard supernatant.
(Surface staining) Stain cells with 50 μL surface staining cocktail with viability dye for 30 min at 4°C, in the dark.
Wash cells with 150 μL FACS buffer. Spin at 390 × g, 5 min at 4°C. Discard supernatant.

(Fixation) Fix cells with 100 μL 1× BD TF Fix buffer for 40 min at 4°C, in the dark.
Change centrifuge speed to 757 × g.
Add 100 μL 1× BD TF Perm Wash. Spin at 757 × g, 5 min at 4°C. Discard supernatant.
Add 200 μL 1× BD TF perm wash to remove the remaining fixative buffer. Spin at 757 × g, 5 min at 4°C. Discard supernatant by pipetting.
Spin again at 757 × g, 5 min at 4°C.
Pipette out and remove remaining excess residual liquid to avoid diluting the staining cocktail.
(Intracellular staining) Stain cells with 50 μL intracellular staining cocktail containing anti-CD3ε and anti-Perforin in 1× BD TF perm wash for 40 min at 4°C, in the dark.
Wash cells with 150 μL 1× BD TF perm wash. Spin at 757× g, 5 min at 4°C. Discard supernatant by pipetting.
Resuspend cells in 100 μL FACS buffer.
Transfer cells to FACS tubes. Store tubes in the dark at 4°C until acquisition.
Acquire cells on a flow cytometer. (Refer to Materials and Equipment)
Export files as Flow Cytometry Standard (FCS) 3.0.
Analyze files using flow-cytometry-based analysis software such as FlowJo.
Part II: Functional analysis—cytotoxicity
Timing: ∼3 days
Note: This part is the continuation of Part I and should be planned accordingly. The overall timeline representation of Part II is depicted in Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]. The suggested experimental layout is outlined in Figure 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig4].

Figure 3. Timeline of the Pa MR1T cell cytotoxicity assay

Figure 4. Plate layout for the Pa MR1T cell cytotoxicity assay
The second part of this protocol is used to examine the cytotoxic potential of the cultured MR1T cells by measuring apoptosis or cell death of cognate antigen-pulsed target cells.

Target cell lines are pulsed with synthetic MR1 ligand 5-OP-RU or riboflavin biosynthesis proficient E. coli, producing these MR1 ligands. Target cells presenting cognate MAIT cell antigens on the MR1 molecule are recognized and killed by the expanded MR1T cells as effector cells, via the release of cytolytic granules such as perforin (Leeansyah et al., 2020b[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib12]). Because MR1 is highly conserved in eutherian mammals, functional cross-reactivity has been observed between pteropid MR1T cells to human MR1 (Leeansyah et al., 2020b[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib12]). Thus, cell lines of both pteropid bat and human origins can be used to assess pteropid MR1T cell cytotoxic capacity.
MR1 antigen/bacterial-pulsing of target cell lines (PaKi, HEK293T-MR1, HeLa) (-3.5 h)
(∼18 h before experiment) Seed cells at 5 × 104 cells per well in 200 μL cell culture media (Media and reagents preparation, point 2), into a 96-well flat bottom plate 18 h before assay.
On the day of experiment: harvest cells from three representative wells and count cells. Use the average cell numbers to determine the bacterial dose required and the number of effector cells at a pre-determined effector:target cell (E:T) ratio. You can use the table below as a guide.
table:files/protocols_protocol_665_16.csv
Remove media and add back 90 μL fresh pre-warm R10 medium.
Note: Pre-warm R10 medium at 37°C.
Prepare formaldehyde-fixed bacteria (−3.5 h) (Dias et al., 2017b[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib5]; Dias et al., 2016[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib6]):
Thaw stock tube on ice, and add 5×108 bacteria into 1 mL PBS in a 1.5 mL tube. Spin at 5000 × g for 3 min at 4°C.
Resuspend bacteria in 500 μL of 1% formaldehyde.
Set timer to 3 min - vortex at maximum speed for the first 60 s, and then again during the final 30 s.
Add 500 μL PBS to wash and spin at 5000 × g for 3 min at 4°C.

Discard supernatant by pipetting.
Resuspend cells in 1 mL PBS to wash. Spin at 5000 × g for 3 min at 4°C. Discard supernatant.
Repeat PBS wash.
Resuspend bacteria in 1 mL cold (2°C–8°C) R10 medium.
Adjust bacteria stock for a bacterial dose of 30 CFU per target cell in 10 μL R10 media with appropriate number of samples.
Note: You can use the table below as a guide for calculation. Bacterial numbers for the bacteria stock should be enumerated before freezing. Refer to previously published protocols for step-by-step guidelines how to enumerate bacterial numbers, which are expressed as colony-forming units (CFU)/mL (Boulouis et al., 2020[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib1]; Sia et al., 2020[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib16]).
table:files/protocols_protocol_665_17.csv
Add 10 μL of adjusted bacteria stock to target cells.
Note: Refer to Figure 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig4] for a plate layout illustration.
Spin at 58× g for 2 min with minimal brake at 23°C–25°C.
Incubate at 37°C in the 5% CO2 incubator for 3 h.
After 1 h of incubation with bacteria, prepare and add 2 nM 5-OP-RU or 25 μM Ac-6-FP to corresponding wells and incubate for 2 h.
Preparation of effector cells (−2 h)
Note: Start preparing the effector cells after the addition of 5-OP-RU and Ac-6-FP to the target cells. Determine purity of effector (expanded MR1T) cells one day before assay by flow-cytometry-based analysis (Point 2).
Collect expanded day 15–18 MR1T cells into a sterile 50 mL falcon tube.
Spin at 390 × g, 5 min at 23°C–25°C. Decant supernatant.
Add 10 mL PBS to wash and perform cell count by Trypan Blue exclusion.
Spin at 390 × g, 5 min at 23°C–25°C. Discard supernatant by pipetting.
Resuspend cells at 5 ×106 cells/mL with PBS.
Dilute CellTrace™ Violet (CTV) stocks 1:50 with PBS, in the dark.
Note: Work in a darkened BSC-II when using CTV.

Add diluted CTV to cells at a 1:100 dilution (final 1:5000), in the dark.
Mix well by gentle vortexing to achieve uniform labeling of effector cells and wrap the tube with aluminum foil.
Incubate tube at 37°C for 30 min in a 5% CO2 incubator.
Add 20 mL of pre-warmed R10 medium to quench reaction.
Incubate for a further 15 min at 37°C in a 5% CO2 incubator.
Spin cells at 390 × g, 5 min at 23°C–25°C to wash.
Wash cells twice with 15 mL pre-warmed (37°C) PBS. Spin cells at 390 × g, 5 min at 23°C–25°C.
Resuspend cells in R10 medium at a determined cell concentration for adjusted E:T ratio, purity, and number of samples per 100 μL.
Note: You can use the table below as a guide for calculation.
table:files/protocols_protocol_665_18.csv
Cytotoxicity assay (at 0 h)
Adjust effector cells to final volume of 100 μL with an effector to target cell (E:T) ratio of 10:1.
Add 100 μL of effector cells to target.
Note: Work in a darkened BSC-II. Refer to Figure 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig4] for a plate layout illustration.
Mix gently and spin at 58× g for 2 min with minimal brake at 23°C–25°C to allow cell-to-cell contact.
Incubate for 24 h at 37°C in a 5% CO2 incubator.
After 24 h, mix wells of the assay-plate and transfer to a 96-well V-bottom plate to collect floating cells. Spin 96-well V-bottom plate at 390 × g, 5 min at 23°C–25°C. Discard supernatant by pipetting.
Resuspend wells of assay plate with 200 μL PBS and transfer PBS wash to the same 96-well V-bottom plate to collect remaining floating cells. Spin V-bottom plate at 390 × g, 5 min at 23°C–25°C. Discard supernatant by pipetting.

Add 30 μL of Trypsin-EDTA to wells of assay-plate and treat cells for 5 min, at 37°C in a 5% CO2 incubator.
Note: PaKi cells can be very adherent to plate. The cells can be trypsinized further but no longer than 10 min. (Troubleshooting – Problem 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec6.7])
Add 100 μL of R10 to wells to stop reaction.
Mix and transfer cells from assay-plate to the same 96-well V-bottom plate. Spin V-bottom plate at 390 × g, 5 min at 23°C–25°C. Discard supernatant.
Wash cells on the V-bottom plate with 200 μL cold (2°C- 8°C) FACS buffer. Spin V-bottom plate at 390× g, 5 min at 23°C–25°C. Discard supernatant by pipetting.
Proceed to staining for flow-cytometry-based analysis.
Note: Refer to Part I, point 2 above for staining. Intracellular staining cocktail for cytotoxicity assay is composed of anti-CD3ε, anti-Perforin and anti-active Caspase 3 diluted in 1× BD TF perm wash.
Note: We recommend titrating the optimal concentration of MR1 ligands and bacterial dose to be used in this experimental set-up. A time-kinetic study is also recommended to identify the best timing for capturing maximum target cell killing, e.g., 3, 6, 12 h. If human cell lines are used as target cells, MR1-dependency of MR1T cell cytotoxicity can be determined by using a blocking monoclonal antibody (mAb) against human MR1 (Leeansyah et al., 2020b[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib12]), clone 26.5 (Biolegend, catalog No. 361103) (Huang et al., 2005[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib8]). No blocking mAb against pteropid MR1 is commercially available at present.

Pause Point: Effector cells for 0-h control can be kept at 4°C and stained together at the assay’s endpoint. Fixed bacteria can be kept on ice for up to 2 hours if cells are not ready. Cytotoxicity assay can be done with expanded cells between day 15–18. Stain expanded culture 1 day before the assay to determine purity of effector cells, which may guide adjustment of the required E:T ratio (Dias et al., 2016[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib6]). Flow-cytometry-based acquisition of stained cells should be done immediately if possible, or the samples can be stored protected from light at 40C for up to 24 h. Due to the cell number limitations, we recommend users to acquire as many cells as possible.
Part III: Functional analysis—cytokine production
Timing: ∼2 days
Note: This part is the continuation of Part I and should be planned accordingly. The overall timeline representation of Part III is depicted in Figure 5[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig5]. Suggested experimental layout is outlined in Figure 6[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig6].

Figure 5. Timeline of the Pa MR1T cell cytokine production assay
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/665-Fig6.jpg
Figure 6. Plate layout for the Pa MR1T cell cytokine production assay
The third part of the protocol explores the cytokine produced by the expanded MR1T cells upon recognition of specific antigens or following phorbol esters and calcium ionophore stimulations. The assay may give insights on how pteropid MR1T cells would orchestrate downstream immune responses via the production of cytokines.

Freshly-thawed autologous bat immune cells will need to be supplied as antigen-presenting cells (APCs) as the expansion procedure depletes the APCs originally contained at the beginning of the expansion culture (Leeansyah et al., 2020b[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib12]). These added autologous APCs will take up the cognate antigens and present them to the expanded Pa MR1T cells. Due to the lack of pteropid bat-specific reagents, we were able to verify only two cytokines that can be readily detected by using the reagents listed in this Protocol: tumor necrosis factor (TNF) and IL-17.
This assay also allows examination of IL-17 and TNF production by freshly-thawed (non-expanded) bat primary immune cells.
Preparation of autologous APCs (−4.5 h)
Thaw cells as described above and determine cell number (Refer to Part I, point 1a).
Seed cells at 5 × 104 cells per well in 90 μL into a sterile 96-well U-bottom plate in R10 medium. Add PBS to empty wells to minimize evaporation.
Note: Refer to Figure 6[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig6] for a plate layout illustration.
Prepare fixed bacteria (−3.5 h) (Refer to Part II, Point 3d)
Adjust fixed bacteria stock for a bacterial dose of 3 CFU per 0.05 × 106 autologous target cell in 10 μL and with number of reactions.
Note: See also Part II, point 3d-ix for guide to calculation. Refer to Figure 6[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig6] for a plate layout illustration.
Incubate for 3 h at 37°C in a 5% CO2 incubator.
Prepare and add 2 nM 5-OP-RU or 25 μM Ac-6-FP and incubate for 2 h at 37°C in 5% CO2 incubator (−2 h).
Note: Add diluted 5-OP-RU and Ac-6-FP immediately. Work in a darkened BSC-II. Refer to Figure 6[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig6] for a plate layout illustration.
Preparation of expanded Pa MR1T cells (−2 h)

Note: Start preparing the effector cells after the addition of 5-OP-RU and Ac-6-FP into the target cells. Determine the purity of expanded MR1T cells one day before assay by flow-cytometry-based analysis (Point 2). Refer to Part II, point 4 for preparation and CTV labelling of the effector cells. Work in a darkened BSC-II when using CTV.
Resuspend CTV-labeled effector cells in R10 medium at adjusted 2.5 × 105 per 100 μL.
Co-culture assay for cytokine detection (start of time = 0 h)
Add 100 μL of effector (Pa MR1T cells) to target cells (autologous APCs) (E:T ratio of 5:1).
Note: Work in a darkened BSC-II. Refer to Figure 6[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig6] for a plate layout illustration.
Mix gently at surface. Incubate for at least 2 h at 37°C in a 5% CO2 incubator.
During the last 6 hours of the assay, add BD Leukocyte Activation Cocktail, with BD GolgiPlug™ (PMA and ionomycin with Brefeldin A) in 1:1000 dilution to PMA control wells. Add BD GolgiStop™ Protein Transport Inhibitor (containing monensin) in 1:1000 dilution to all wells.
Note: Work in a darkened BSC-II. Refer to Figure 6[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig6] for a plate layout illustration.
At the experimental endpoint, mix and transfer cells to a 96-well V-bottom plate. Spin the V-bottom plate at 390 × g, 5 min at 23°C–25°C. Discard supernatant.
Wash assay plate once with 200 μL of PBS and transfer the PBS wash to the same V-bottom plate. Spin V-bottom plate at 390 × g, 5 min at 23°C–25°C. Discard supernatant.
Proceed to staining for flow-cytometry-based analysis.
Note: Refer to Part I, point 2 above for staining. Intracellular cocktail for cytokine assay staining would be anti-CD3ε, anti-TNF, and anti-IL17 diluted in 1× BD TF perm wash.

Note: We recommend titrating the optimal concentrations of MR1 ligands and bacterial dose. A time-kinetic study is also recommended to identify the best timing for capturing maximum cytokine production: e.g., 8, 10, 12, 24, 48, and 72 h of co-culture.
Pause Point: This assay can be done with expanded cells between day 15–18. Stain expanded culture 1 day before the assay to determine purity of effector cells, which may guide adjustment of the required E:T ratio (Dias et al., 2016[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib6]). Flow-cytometry-based acquisition of stained cells should be done immediately if possible, or the samples can be stored protected from light at 40C for up to 24 h.
Part IV: Functional analysis—antigen-specific MR1T cell proliferation
Timing: ∼Recommended up to 3–10 days
This part examines the antigen-specific requirements of Pa MR1T cell proliferation. The overall timeline representation of Part IV is depicted in Figure 7[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig7]. Suggested experimental layout is outlined in Figure 8[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig8].

Note: CTV is light-sensitive reagent. Work with minimal light exposure.
Labeling and culturing cells – refer to thawing step above (point 1a)
Thaw and count cells as above (Refer to Part I, point 1a).
Resuspend cells in 5 × 106 cells/mL of PBS.
Collect and store 104 cells at 4°C for non-CTV control.
Note: Store cells at 4°C until staining step point 10. If possible, also store 106 unlabeled cells for in-culture compensation control.
Prepare a diluted stock of CTV in 1:40 with PBS.
Add diluted CTV to cells at 1:100 (final concentration 1:4000) and proceed with CTV-labeling of cells as described in Part II, point 4.

Note: Important to mix well with gentle vortexing. Wrap tube with foil. Always work in a darkened BSC-II when using CTV.
Resuspend CTV-labeled cells at 106 cells per 190 μL with expansion media (1× IC expansion media).
Note: Work in a darkened BSC-II to preserve CTV signal.
Take an aliquot of 106 CTV-labeled cells for day 0 baseline staining. Also take an aliquot of 104 CTV-labeled cells as a CTV compensation control; this won’t be stained). Store cells for staining.
Note: Store cells in dark at 4°C until staining step, point 10.
Plate cells into sterile 96-well U-bottom plate at 190 μL per well.
Note: Refer to Figure 8[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig8] for experimental plating layout.
Prepare formaldehyde-fixed E. coli (Refer to Part II, point 3d):
Resuspend fixed bacteria in 1 mL IC culture media.
Adjust and prepare MR1 ligands: 10 nM 5-OP-RU, or 25 μM Ac-6-FP, or formaldehyde-fixed E. coli at bacterial dose of 0.1 CFU/cell, diluted in IC expansion media. Add to plated cells in 10 μL to a final culture volume of 200 μL per well.
Note: Add diluted 5-OP-RU and Ac-6-FP immediately to the cells.
Add 200 μL PBS to remaining empty wells to reduce evaporation of culture media.
Culture plate at 37°C in a 5% CO2 incubator.
Replace half of the media every 2 days with IC expansion media containing 2× IL-2 and IL-7 cytokines.
Note: Work in a darkened BSC-II to preserve CTV signal.
Perform cell count and stain cells on day 3, 5, 7 and 10 to determine expansion based on cell numbers CTV dilution. (Troubleshooting – Problem 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec6.5])
Staining cells for flow-cytometry-based analysis.
Transfer the collected 106 CTV-labeled cells (Part IV, point 9 g) into a 96-well V-bottom plate.

Note: We recommend a time-kinetic study to identify the best timing for capturing the most discernable CTV dilution peaks. We recommend day 3, 5, 7, and 10 post-stimulation. Take 50 μL of culture from well for staining. Work in a darkened BSC-II.
Wash once with 200 μL FACS buffer. Spin at 390 × g, 5 min at 4°C. Discard supernatant.
(Blocking) Add 50 μL of 10% FCS or if available, 10% bat serum diluted in FACS buffer to block cells for 30 min at 4°C.
Wash cells with 150 μL FACS buffer. Spin at 390 × g, 5 min at 4°C. Discard supernatant.
(hMR1-5-OP-RU tetramer staining) Stain cells with 50 μL diluted fluorochrome conjugated - hMR1-5-OP-RU and hMR1-6-FP tetramer for 40 min at 23°C–25°C, in dark.
Wash cells with 150 μL FACS buffer. Spin at 390 × g, 5 min at 4°C. Discard supernatant.
(Surface staining) Stain cells with 50 μL surface staining cocktail with viability dye for 30 min at 4°C, in dark.
Transfer previously prepared aliquots of CTV-labeled cells for compensation control (point 9c and 9 g) to the empty wells on the V-bottom plate.
Note: CTV compensation control cells (point 9c and 9g) can be fixed separately or done together on the same staining plate. Compensation set-up has been thoroughly described in our previous publication (Dias et al., 2017b[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib5]).
Wash cells with 150 μL FACS buffer. Spin at 390 × g, 5 min at 4°C. Discard supernatant by pipetting.
(Fixation) Fix cells with 100 μL 1× BD TF Fix buffer for 40 min at 4°C, in dark.
Add 100 μL 1× BD TF Perm Wash. Spin at 757 × g, 5 min at 4°C.

Discard supernatant by pipetting. Wash with 200 μL 1×BD TF perm wash to remove remaining fixative. Spin at 757 × g, 5 min at 4°C.
Discard supernatant by pipetting. Spin at 757× g, 5 min at 4°C.
Remove remaining excess residual liquid by pipetting.
(Intracellular/intranuclear staining) Stain cells with 50 μL intracellular staining cocktail containing anti-CD3ε, and (optional) anti-T-bet, anti-Eomes, anti-PLZF, and anti-RORγt antibodies in 1× BD TF perm wash for 40 min at 4°C, in dark.
Wash cells with 150 μL 1× BD TF perm wash. Spin at 757× g, 5 min at 4°C. Discard supernatant.
Resuspend cells in 100 μL FACS buffer.
Transfer cells to FACS tubes. Store tubes in dark at 4°C until acquisition.
Acquire cells on a flow cytometer. (Refer to Materials and Equipment).
Critical: 5-OP-RU degrades rapidly upon exposure to aqueous solution and Ac-6-FP may be sensitive to light. Only add 5-OP-RU into culture media immediately before the intended experiments (within 2 min). Preferably work in a darkened BSC-II. We recommend titrating 5-OP-RU, Ac-6-FP, and the bacterial dose (i.e., CFU/cell) to determine the optimal concentrations for your experimental set-up. Minimize light exposure when working with CTV-labelled cells. If possible, also set apart ∼106 unlabeled and CTV-labeled cells and culture in IC culture media throughout the culturing experiment; they can be used to set up compensation matrix and as a fluorescence minus one (FMO) control on the day of the assay.
Pause Point: Flow-cytometry-based acquisition of stained cells should be done immediately if possible, or the samples can be stored protected from light at 40C for up to 24 h.
